form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Coburn introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Armed Services

form.official-title: To prevent the militarization of Federal, State, and local law enforcement by Federal excess property transfers and grant programs.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Stop Militarizing Law Enforcement Act
.

section.header: Additional limitations on transfer of Department of Defense personal property to Federal and State law enforcement agencies

paragraph.text: Section 2576a of title 10, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: in subsection (a)—

subclause.text: in the matter preceding subparagraph (A), by striking subsection (b) and inserting the provisions of this section; and
in subparagraph (A), by striking , including counter-drug and counterterrorism activities; and

clause.text: in paragraph (2), by striking and the Director of National Drug Control Policy;

subparagraph.text: in subsection (b)—

clause.text: in paragraph (3), by striking and at the end;
in paragraph (4), by striking the period and inserting a semicolon; and
by adding at the end the following new paragraphs:

paragraph.text: the recipient certifies to the Department of Defense that it has the personnel and technical capacity, including training, to operate the property; and

the recipient certifies to the Department of Defense that if the recipient determines that the property is surplus to the needs of the recipient, the recipient will return the property to the Department of Defense.

subparagraph.text: by striking subsection (d); and
by adding at the end the following new subsections:

subsection.text: The Secretary of Defense may not transfer under this section any property as follows:

paragraph.text: Weapons, weapon parts, and weapon components, including camouflage and deception equipment, and optical sights.
Weapon system specific vehicular accessories.
Demolition materials.
Explosive ordinance.
Night vision equipment.
Tactical clothing, including uniform clothing and footwear items, special purpose clothing items, and specialized flight clothing and accessories.
Drones.
Combat, assault, and tactical vehicles, including Mine-Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) vehicles.
Training aids and devices.

subsection.header: Approval by law required for transfer of property not previously transferrable

paragraph.text: In the event the Secretary of Defense proposes to make available for transfer under this section any property of the Department of Defense not previously made available for transfer under this section, the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report setting forth the following:

subparagraph.text: A description of the property proposed to be made available for transfer.
A description of the conditions, if any, to be imposed on use of the property after transfer.
A certification that transfer of the property would not violate a provision of this section or any other provision of law.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not transfer any property covered by a report under this subsection unless authorized by a law enacted by Congress after the date of the receipt of the report by Congress.

subsection.header: Annual certification accounting for transferred property

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Defense shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress each year a certification in writing that each recipient to which the Secretary has transferred property under this section during the preceding fiscal year—

subparagraph.text: has provided to the Secretary documentation accounting for all property the Secretary has previously transferred to such recipient under this section; and
has complied with paragraphs (5) and (6) of subsection (b) with respect to the property so transferred during such fiscal year.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary cannot provide a certification under paragraph (1) for a recipient, the Secretary may not transfer additional property to such recipient under this section, effective as of the date on which the Secretary would otherwise make the certification under this subsection, and such recipient shall be suspended or terminated from further receipt of property under this section.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, amounts authorized to be appropriated or otherwise made available for any fiscal year may not be obligated or expended to carry out this section unless the Secretary submits to the appropriate committees of Congress a certification that for the preceding fiscal year that—

paragraph.text: each recipient agency that has received property under this section has—

subparagraph.text: demonstrated 100 percent accountability for all such property, in accordance with paragraph (2) or (3), as applicable; or
been suspended or terminated from the program pursuant to paragraph (4);

paragraph.text: with respect to each non-Federal agency that has received property under this section, the State Coordinator responsible for each such agency has verified that the State Coordinator or an agent of the State Coordinator has conducted an in-person inventory of the property transferred to the agency and that 100 percent of such property was accounted for during the inventory or that the agency has been suspended or terminated from the program pursuant to paragraph (4);

with respect to each Federal agency that has received property under this section, the Secretary of Defense or an agent of the Secretary has conducted an in-person inventory of the property transferred to the agency and that 100 percent of such property was accounted for during the inventory or that the agency has been suspended or terminated from the program pursuant to paragraph (4);

the eligibility of any agency that has received property under this section for which 100 percent of the equipment was not accounted for during an inventory described in paragraph (2) or (3), as applicable, to receive property transferred under this section has been suspended or terminated; and
each State Coordinator has certified, for each non-Federal agency located in the State for which the State Coordinator is responsible that—

subparagraph.text: the agency has complied with all requirements under this section; or
the eligibility of the agency to receive property transferred under this section has been suspended or terminated; and

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Defense has certified, for each Federal agency that has received property under this section that—

subparagraph.text: the agency has complied with all requirements under this section; or
the eligibility of the agency to receive property transferred under this section has been suspended or terminated.

subsection.text: The Defense Logistics Agency shall maintain, and update on a quarterly basis, an Internet website on which the following information shall be made publicly available in a searchable format:

paragraph.text: A description of each transfer made under this section, including transfers made before the date of the enactment of the Stop Militarizing Law Enforcement Act, set forth by State, county, and recipient agency, and including item name, item type, item model, and quantity.
A list of all property transferred under this section that is not accounted for by the Defense Logistics Agency, including—

subparagraph.text: the name of the State, county, and recipient agency;
the item name, item type, and item model;
the date on which such property became unaccounted for by the Defense Logistics Agency; and
the current status of such item.

paragraph.text: A list of each agency suspended or terminated from further receipt of property under this section, including State, county, and agency, and the reason for and duration of such suspension or termination.
The term appropriate committees of Congress means—

subparagraph.text: the Committee on Armed Services and the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate; and
the Committee on Armed Services and the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of the House of Representatives.

paragraph.text: The term agent of a State Coordinator means any individual to whom a State Coordinator formally delegates responsibilities for the duties of the State Coordinator to conduct inventories described in subsection (g)(2).
The term State Coordinator, with respect to a State, means the individual appointed by the governor of the State to maintain property accountability records and oversee property use by the State.
The amendments made by this subsection shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.

subsection.header: Return of property to Department of Defense
subsection.text: Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act, each Federal or State agency to which property described by subsection (d) of section 2576a of title 10, United States Code (as added by subsection (a)(1) of this section), was transferred before the date of the enactment of this Act shall return such property to the Defense Logistics Agency on behalf of the Department of Defense.

section.header: Use of Department of Homeland Security preparedness grant funds

paragraph.text: the term Agency means the Federal Emergency Management Agency; and
the term preparedness grant program includes—

subparagraph.text: the Port Security Grant Program authorized under section 70107 of title 46, United States Code; and
any other non-disaster preparedness grant program of the Agency.

subsection.text: The Agency may not permit awards under a preparedness grant program—

paragraph.text: to be used to buy, maintain, or alter—

subparagraph.text: tactical law enforcement protective equipment, including—

clause.text: battle dress uniforms, coveralls, and jumpsuits worn during tactical operations, boots, or other specialized tactical clothing or footwear; and

subparagraph.text: explosive entry equipment;
portable or transportable explosive magazines;
head and face protection equipment, other than those to be used by certified bomb technicians;
robot and remotely piloted vehicles, including upgrades, attachments or tools for robots and remotely piloted vehicles;
canines (other than bomb-sniffing canines for agencies with certified bomb technicians);
tactical or armored vehicles;
law enforcement surveillance equipment;
long range hailing and warning devices; or
tactical entry equipment; or

paragraph.text: to be used for, or to deploy or obtain training in the use or deployment of—

subparagraph.text: robots and remotely piloted vehicles;
canines (other than bomb-sniffing canines for agencies with certified bomb technicians);
explosive entry equipment;
law enforcement surveillance equipment; or
tactical operations.

subsection.header: Review of prior receipt of property before award
subsection.text: In making an award under a preparedness grant program, the Agency shall—

paragraph.text: determine whether the awardee has already received, and still retains, property from the Department of Defense pursuant to section 2576a of title 10, United States Code, including through review of the website maintained by the Defense Logistics Agency pursuant to subsection (h) of such section (as added by section 2(a)(1) of this Act); and
require that the award may not be used by the awardee to procure or obtain property determined to be retained by the awardee pursuant to paragraph (1).

subsection.header: Use of grant program funds for required return of property to DoD
subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the use of funds by a State or local agency to return to the Department of Defense property transferred to such State or local agency pursuant to section 2676a of title 10, United States Code, as such return is required by section 2(b) of this Act, shall be an allowable use of preparedness grant program funds by such agency.

section.header: Use of Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant funds

subsection.text: Section 501(d) of title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 (42 U.S.C. 3751(d)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The purchase, maintenance, alteration, or operation of—

subparagraph.text: lethal weapons; or
less-lethal weapons.

subsection.header: Use of grant funds for required return of property to DoD
subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the use of funds by a State agency or unit of local government to return to the Department of Defense property transferred to such agency or unit of local government pursuant to section 2676a of title 10, United States Code, as such return is required by section 2(b) of this Act, shall be an allowable use of grant amounts under the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program.
